value: We can write “$6$ times the age of Rodey” as $6a.$
“$3$ years older” means we need to add $3.$
So “$3$ years older than $6$ times the age of Rodney” can be written as $6a+3.$
Rodney’s father “is $43$ years old” means we set the equation equal to $43.$
That means the equation that we can use to find the age of Rodney is $6a+3=43.$
We can write “half the weight of Cassandra’s bag” as $\frac{1}{2}w.$
“$4$ pounds less than” means we need to subtract $4.$
So “$4$ pounds less than half the weight of Cassandra’s bag” can be written as $\frac{1}{2}w-4.$
Charlotte’s bag “weighs $16$ pounds” means we set the equation equal to $16.$
That means the equation that we can use to find the weight of Cassandra’s bag is $\frac{1}{2}w-4=16.$
We can write “$3.3$ times the distance that Oliver ran” as $3.3d.$
“$4.5$ meters more than” means we need to add $4.5.$
So “$4.5$ meters more than $3.3$ times the distance that Oliver ran” can be written as $3.3d+4.5.$
Liam ran “a total of $437.6$ meters,” which means we set the equation equal to $437.6.$
That means the equation that we can use to find the distance that Oliver ran is $3.3d+4.5=437.6.$
We can write “$9$ times the amount of money that Cesar spent” as $9m.$
“$7$ dollars less than” means we need to subtract $7.$
So “$7$ dollars less than $9$ times the amount of money that Cesar spent” can be written as $9m-7.$
Bernardo “spent a total of $17$ dollars” means we set the equation equal to $17.$
That means the equation that we can use to find the amount of money that Cesar spent is $9m-7 = 17.$
We can write “$6$ times the amount of time that Keira slept” as $6t.$
“$25$ minutes less than” means we need to subtract $25.$
So “$25$ minutes less than $6$ times the amount of time that Keira slept” can be written as $6t-25.$
Flannery “slept for a total of $35$ minutes” means we set the equation equal to $35.$
That means the equation that we can use to find the amount of time that Keira slept is $6t-25 = 35.$
We can write “$1.8$ times the height of Rory” as $1.8h.$
“$4.5$ centimeters taller than” means we need to add $4.5.$
So “$4.5$ centimeters taller than $1.8$ times the height of Rory” can be written as $1.8h+4.5.$
Tyler “is $87.6$ centimeters tall” means we set the equation equal to $87.6.$
That means the equation that we can use to find the height of Rory is $1.8h+4.5 = 87.6.$
We can write “half the weight of a pumpkin” as $\frac{1}{2}w.$
“$6$ pounds lighter than” means we need to subtract $6.$
So “$6$ pounds lighter than half the weight of a pumpkin” can be written as $\frac{1}{2}w-6.$
The watermelon “weighs $20$ pounds” means we set the equation equal to $20.$
That means the equation that we can use to find the weight of the pumpkin is $\frac{1}{2}w-6=20.$
We can write “$3$ times the amount of time that Edison studied” as $3m.$
“$2\frac{1}{2}$ minutes longer than” means we need to add $2\frac{1}{2}.$
So “$2\frac{1}{2}$ minutes longer than $3$ times the amount of time that Edison studied” can be written as $3t+2\frac{1}{2}.$
Sabrina “spent $15$ minutes studying” means we set the equation equal to $15.$
That means the equation that we can use to find the time that Edison spent studying is $3t+2\frac{1}{2}=15.$
We can write “twice the number of flowers that Jace planted” as $2f.$
“$4$ more flowers than” means we need to add $4.$
So “$4$ more flowers than twice the number of flowers that Jace planted” can be written as $2f+4.$
Thomson “planted $14$ flowers” means we set the equation equal to $14.$
That means the equation that we can use to find the number of flowers that Jace planted is $2f+4=14.$
We can write “$3$ times the age of Nina” as $3a.$
“$11$ years younger than” means we need to subtract $11.$
So “$11$ years younger than $3$ times the age of Nina” can be written as $3a-11.$
Lily “is $4$ years old” means we set the equation equal to $4.$
That means the equation that we can use to find the age of the Nina is $3a-11=4.$
